awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative research: Data driven discovery of synthesis pathways and distinguishing electronic phenomena of 1D van der Waals bonded solids
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: This project explores a recently discovered class of more than 400 materials that form one-dimensional wires of bonded atoms surrounded by a tubular, two-dimensional van der Waals gap avoiding any strong atomic bonds between wires. A combination of predictive computational techniques, chemical preparation, and physical characterization will be employed to identify a spectrum of scientifically and technologically important properties of these materials with a focus on electrical transport properties, mechanical response and stability, and phase transformations. This project aims to leverage a spectrum of data mining, machine learning, and materials property calculation techniques to accelerate the identification of the most promising subset of these 400 materials for synthesis and testing. The PIs will train the next generation of scientists and engineers by providing interdisciplinary research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students with attention given to attracting those from underrepresented groups. Emphasis will be placed on training with respect to computationally-led and data-drive approaches to materials research. Specifically, undergraduate students will develop Java-based software for materials science and graduate students will host a podcast aimed at disseminating developments in data-driven computational science.

Technical Description: Bulk crystals of graphite and other materials composed of 2-dimensional van der Waals (vdW) layers exhibit numerous important properties in the bulk that are preserved as the material is thinned to atomic thickness, e.g. the high electrical conductivity of graphene. This distinguishes them from native bulk materials that do not exhibit such vdW layered structure, such as copper, whose properties change dramatically as it is thinned below a few atomic layers. Unlike 2D layered materials, the 1-dimensional vdW materials of this project have received relatively little research attention, but are likely to exhibit many of the useful properties of their 2D counterparts. One hypothesis is that the presence of vdW gaps and the absence of dangling bonds and large single crystal domains inhibits carrier scattering at the surface of such materials and, thus, allows for electronic transport at a resistivity almost independent of wire cross section. Recent synthesis work by the project participants has revealed excellent transport properties of such materials when thinned to nanoscale cross sections, rivaling the favorable characteristics of the native bulk form of copper, with potential applications in the miniaturization of electronic devices. Another hypothesis is that these materials may be more likely to exhibit electronic or structural phase changes that can be engineered for low power electronic memories and other applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project, which included co-PIs at UC Riverside, focused on elucidating the new, distinguishing, and potentially useful properties of 1D van-der-Waals (vdW) bonded crystals. This class of materials was identified through data mining techniques to contain about 500 members, yet their properties have received little attention compared to the 2D vdW bonded counterparts. Accomplishing this task requires a broad survey of these materials, which we have performed by coupling a computational survey of the major classes with synthesis and characterization. This project accelerated the study and adaptation of these materials by providing initial answers to “What is interesting about these materials?” for other researchers.

Within the spirit of the DMREF program, the co-PIs employed a combination of materials growth, characterization, electronic structure calculations, and database curation, in a closed loop collaboration, to identify, grow, and characterize the most unique and useful candidates. Materials were screened using data mining techniques, and the electronic, phonon, and thermal properties of the most promising materials were characterized experimentally.

We highlight some of the outcomes from our project:

1.     Machine-learning discovery of novel 1D materials: We developed a machine-learned (ML) approach to dramatically expand the phase space of 1D materials, predicting hundreds to thousands of novel 1D materials – a dramatic expansion from the ~500 1D vdW materials previously known. Our models can further be used to select metallic 1D materials, which may play an important role as future nanoscale interconnect materials.

2.     Closed-loop experimental and computational collaboration on MoI3: We worked in a close-looped fashion with our experimental co-PIs, wherein we predicted that MoI3 could be synthesized as a 1D vdW material. Our collaborators have successfully synthesized this wire-like material, which showed a vibrational spectrum in very good agreement with our predictions, showcasing the success of our closed-loop experimental-computational DMREF team.

3.     Data-informed prediction of new materials for interconnect applications: We identified 10 candidate compound metals as Cu alternatives for local interconnect applications that holistically display large bulk electronic conductivity, low surface electronic scattering, thermodynamic stability, and compatibility with common substrates and gases. Starting from our calculations and working in a collaborative project with experimental collaborators, we further validated the potential of CoPt – one of the identified materials – for interconnect applications by performing first-principles transport calculations.

4.     A methodology for targeted experimental material discovery using Bayesian Algorithm Execution (BAX): We formulated the process of experimental discovery as a subspace identification problem, which allows us to construct goal-aware multi-objective acquisition functions. Our approach outperforms existing methods in both theoretical and experimental datasets and could be broadly utilized in other materials discovery efforts.

The work led to several publications and datasets. All codes and datasets produced are available through GitHub repositories, data deposition websites, and supplemental information alongside the published manuscript. This award supported three graduate students at Stanford, and various summer REU students.


Last Modified: 07/05/2024
Modified by: Felipe Homrich Da Jornada
